title: 106_hr5212
content: The Act is titled the "Veterans' Oral History Project Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings section. Congress finds that military service during times of war is a significant sacrifice, with millions of Americans serving in various conflicts throughout the 20th century. The Department of Veterans Affairs reports nearly 19 million war veterans living in the country today. Despite this, the number of living veterans from World War I and World War II is dwindling, highlighting the importance of preserving oral histories for future generations. Oral histories of American war veterans are invaluable for preserving the memories and experiences of those who served in conflicts. Collecting and cataloging these stories is essential for future generations to understand the heroics, horrors, and triumphs of war. The Library of Congress, as the Nation's oldest Federal cultural institution and largest library in human history, aims to collect, preserve, and make available oral histories of American war veterans. This Act establishes a federally sponsored program to coordinate the collection of video and audio recordings of personal histories and testimonials of veterans, aiming to preserve their memories for future generations. The Act aims to collect oral histories of American war veterans to preserve their memories for future generations and help Americans better understand the realities of war and sacrifices made by those who served. Establishment of program at American Folklife Center to collect video and audio recordings of histories of veterans. The Director of the American Folklife Center at the Library of Congress will establish an oral history program to collect video and audio recordings of personal histories of veterans of the Armed Forces who served during war. The program will also include creating a collection of these recordings, soliciting and cataloging written materials such as letters and diaries related to the veterans' personal histories. The Director may establish partnerships with other entities to carry out activities related to collecting video and audio recordings of veterans' personal histories. The Director will begin collecting recordings from the oldest veterans as soon as possible after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. PRIVATE SUPPORT. The Librarian of Congress can accept donations for the oral history program under section 3 and establish a separate gift account in the Treasury for this purpose. Donated funds must be deposited into the gift account and used solely for the oral history program. The Librarian can accept donations for the oral history program under section 3, which must be used exclusively for that purpose. Any funds not designated for the oral history program cannot be accepted. Authorization of appropriations for this Act includes $250,000 for fiscal year 2001 and necessary sums for each succeeding fiscal year.
